unnormalised: ### Navigating the Labyrinth: My Experience with Family Law in India
normalised: ### Navigating the Labyrinth: My Experience with Family Law in India

unnormalised: My cousin, Priya Sharma, always had a bright smile. It could light up a room, chase away the monsoon gloom even in Mumbai. But recently, that smile had faded, replaced by a weary resignation. Priya, a lecturer at a local college, found herself entangled in the complexities of family law after a deeply unfortunate marriage.
normalised: My cousin, Priya Sharma, always had a bright smile. It could light up a room, chase away the monsoon gloom even in Mumbai. But recently, that smile had faded, replaced by a weary resignation. Priya, a lecturer at a local college, found herself entangled in the complexities of family law after a deeply unfortunate marriage.

unnormalised: The initial cracks appeared subtly. Disagreements over finances escalated. Soon, the once-loving home transformed into a battleground. When things spiralled beyond repair, Priya decided to file for divorce. That’s when the labyrinth of legal procedures began. First, she needed a lawyer. Adv. Verma, recommended by a friend, seemed competent. He charged Rs. 15,000 for the initial consultation and advised her on Section 13 of the Hindu Marriage Act, the relevant section for divorce on grounds of cruelty.
normalised: The initial cracks appeared subtly. Disagreements over finances escalated. Soon, the once-loving home transformed into a battleground. When things spiraled beyond repair, Priya decided to file for divorce. That’s when the labyrinth of legal procedures began. First, she needed a lawyer. Advocate Verma, recommended by a friend, seemed competent. He charged rupee fifteen thousand for the initial consultation and advised her on Section thirteen of the Hindu Marriage Act, the relevant section for divorce on grounds of cruelty.

unnormalised: The court dates were endless. Case no. 456/2023 dragged on for months. Attending the court in Thane felt like stepping into another world. The sheer volume of cases, the tired faces of litigants, the hushed whispers – it was overwhelming. Priya also sought maintenance under Section 125 of the CrPC, given she was the primary caregiver to their son, Rohan. The judge initially awarded Rs. 10,000/month, a paltry sum considering Mumbai's cost of living.
normalised: The court dates were endless. Case number four hundred and fifty six divided by two thousand and twenty three dragged on for months. Attending the court in Thane felt like stepping into another world. The sheer volume of cases, the tired faces of litigants, the hushed whispers – it was overwhelming. Priya also sought maintenance under Section one hundred and twenty five of the C-R-P-C, given she was the primary caregiver to their son, Rohan. The judge initially awarded rupee ten thousand per month, a paltry sum considering Mumbai's cost of living.

unnormalised: Child custody became a particularly painful point. Priya wanted Rohan to stay with her, naturally. Her husband, however, demanded joint custody. Several hearings later, the court granted Priya primary custody but allowed her husband visitation rights every other weekend. Rohan, bless his heart, was only 7 years old and bore the brunt of it all, even though Priya tried her best to shield him. She enrolled him in extra-curricular classes to keep his mind occupied.

unnormalised: The entire process took almost 2 years. It drained Priya emotionally and financially. The legal fees, totaling approx. ₹2 lakhs, were a significant burden. Finally, the divorce was granted on 10/11/2024. Priya emerged, scarred but stronger.
normalised: The entire process took almost two years. It drained Priya emotionally and financially. The legal fees, totaling approximately rupee two hundred thousand, were a significant burden. Finally, the divorce was granted on tenth november two thousand and twenty four. Priya emerged, scarred but stronger.

unnormalised: Her story, while deeply personal, highlights the challenges many women face navigating family law in India. It's a system that can be slow, expensive, and emotionally taxing. But Priya's resilience also serves as a beacon of hope, a reminder that even in the darkest of times, there is light at the end of the tunnel. And slowly, the bright smile is returning, one day at a time.
